G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Under **G.L. c. 208, § 28**, a custody order may be modified upon a showing of a **material and substantial change in circumstances** and that modification would serve the **best interests of the children**.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: Similarly, **G.L. c. 209C, § 20** authorizes modification of custody and visitation judgments under analogous circumstances.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 215, § 6 and G.L. c. 209C, § 20, as this matter concerns custody and visitation of minor children residing in Worcester County.

G.L. c. 223A, \u00a7 3.proposition: Venue is proper in the Worcester Probate and Family Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223A, § 3, because both parties and the children reside within the jurisdiction of this Court.

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have consistently held that the paramount consideration in all custody and visitation matters is the **best interests of the child** (*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); *Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406 (1976); *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003)).
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly frames the governing standard in custody and removal matters as the best interests of the child, interpreting the removal statute’s “upon cause shown” language to mean best interests. It reiterates that, although the court considers the custodial parent’s and noncustodial parent’s interests, the children’s best interests remain the paramount concern. This directly supports the proposition that Massachusetts courts treat the best interests of the child as the paramount consideration in custody/visitation contexts.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that… ‘upon cause shown’… The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child… and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined. … Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern, ‘[b]ecause the best interests of a child are so interwoven with the well-being of the custodial parent, the determination of the child’s best interest requires that the-interests of the custodial parent be taken into account.’”}

*Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406 (1976.proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have consistently held that the paramount consideration in all custody and visitation matters is the **best interests of the child** (*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); *Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406 (1976); *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003)).
*Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406 (1976.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely states that in custody determinations the governing and dominating principle is the welfare of the child, citing earlier SJC cases, and affirms the probate judge’s decree on that basis. This is substantively equivalent to the “best interests of the child” standard described in the proposition and is applied as the paramount consideration over parental claims and wishes. Thus, Vilakazi v. Maxie is accurately cited for the principle that custody and visitation decisions turn on the child’s best interests.
*Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406 (1976.relevant_excerpt: “In Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545, 555 (1930), we stated the basic rule applicable in such cases as follows: ‘The governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child. That is so both as matter of law and as matter of humanity. Every public and private consideration establishes this as the dominating rule.’ We repeated that same language in Jenkins v. Jenkins… and added: ‘…the happiness and the welfare of the child should be the controlling consideration.’”

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court and Appeals Court have consistently held that the paramount consideration in all custody and visitation matters is the **best interests of the child** (*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); *Vilakazi v. Maxie*, 371 Mass. 406 (1976); *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003)).
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses the governing standard in custody and visitation cases and explicitly reiterates that the ‘best interests of the child’ is the controlling and longstanding principle in Massachusetts. It cites earlier SJC precedents, including Yannas, and states that the best interests standard has long been used for custody and visitation determinations. Thus, Custody of Kali directly supports the proposition that the paramount consideration in custody and visitation matters is the best interests of the child.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649, 657 (2002)… (best interests standard ‘has long been used in Massachusetts to decide issues of custody and visitation’); Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’).”

*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.proposition: A substantial change in living conditions or the introduction of risk factors such as household instability, domestic violence, or exposure to individuals with violent criminal histories constitutes a material change justifying modification (*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); *Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981)).
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on the need for explicit findings about the impact of domestic violence on the child and the risks of awarding custody to an abusive parent, but it is not a modification case and does not frame these issues as a “material change” in circumstances justifying modification of an existing order. Instead, it addresses legal error in the original custody adjudication and remands for further findings. Thus, while it strongly emphasizes the relevance of domestic violence and household risk factors to custody determinations, it does not itself establish the specific modification principle stated in the proposition.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.relevant_excerpt: “We agree with the Appeals Court that the judge below ‘fail[ed] to make detailed and comprehensive findings of fact on the issues of domestic violence and its effect upon the child as well as upon the father’s parenting ability.’ … The Probate Court failed to consider the special risks to the child in awarding custody to a father who had committed acts of violence against the mother. … Domestic violence is an issue too fundamental and frequently recurring to be dealt with only by implication.”

*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: A substantial change in living conditions or the introduction of risk factors such as household instability, domestic violence, or exposure to individuals with violent criminal histories constitutes a material change justifying modification (*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); *Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981)).
*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss modification standards, material change, or specific risk factors like domestic violence or exposure to violent individuals. Instead, it addresses initial custody determination and reiterates that custody decisions must be based on the child’s welfare and consideration of all relevant factors, rejecting the use of custody to punish a parent. It therefore does not establish or affirm the proposition that substantial changes in living conditions or risk factors constitute a material change justifying modification.
*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied)… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed… The award of custody to one parent is not a device to be used by judges to discipline the other parent for his or her ‘shortcomings.’”

*Custody of Dorota*, 79 Mass. App. Ct. 1.proposition: Massachusetts courts have also emphasized that domestic violence or exposure to volatile or unsafe environments may justify modification or imposition of supervised visitation to protect children from harm (*Custody of Dorota*, 79 Mass. App. Ct. 1110 (2011); *Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981); *Care and Protection of Zita*, 455 Mass. 272 (2009)).

*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.proposition: Massachusetts courts have also emphasized that domestic violence or exposure to volatile or unsafe environments may justify modification or imposition of supervised visitation to protect children from harm (*Custody of Dorota*, 79 Mass. App. Ct. 1110 (2011); *Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981); *Care and Protection of Zita*, 455 Mass. 272 (2009)).
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.support_reasoning: The opinion in Rolde concerns custody, property division, and a reduction (not supervision) of the father’s visitation based on parental conflict and the best-interests standard. The court does not discuss domestic violence, volatile or unsafe environments, or supervised visitation; it only approves reducing the amount of visitation time. Thus, Rolde does not provide authority for the proposition that domestic violence or unsafe environments may justify imposing supervised visitation.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.relevant_excerpt: "From our above discussion of the record, it should be readily apparent that in view of the circumstances and the personalities involved the judge was justified in reducing the husband's visitation to less than it previously had been under the temporary custody order... '[T]he "best interests" of the child[ren] are to be promoted, and when the parents are at odds [as here], the attainment of that purpose may involve some limitation of the liberties of one or other of the parents.'"

*Care and Protection of Zita*, 455 Mass..proposition: Massachusetts courts have also emphasized that domestic violence or exposure to volatile or unsafe environments may justify modification or imposition of supervised visitation to protect children from harm (*Custody of Dorota*, 79 Mass. App. Ct. 1110 (2011); *Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981); *Care and Protection of Zita*, 455 Mass. 272 (2009)).
*Care and Protection of Zita*, 455 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion in Care and Protection of Zita focuses on evidentiary and procedural errors at a 72‑hour care and protection hearing, particularly improper reliance on facts not in evidence and prior related proceedings. It does not discuss domestic violence, volatile or unsafe home environments, or standards for modifying or imposing supervised visitation. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the proposition that domestic violence or unsafe environments may justify modification or supervised visitation.
*Care and Protection of Zita*, 455 Mass..relevant_excerpt: When we strip from the decision below the information contained in the petition, which was not in evidence, and information the judge may have learned from the earlier care and protection cases, also not in evidence, we are left with grave concerns that the department fell short of meeting its statutory obligation of demonstrating that the newborn infant was in “immediate danger of serious abuse or neglect” and that “immediate removal” was necessary to protect her. Care & Protection of Robert, 408 Mass. 52, 57 (1990).

*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).proposition: In determining the children’s best interests, the Court must consider the fitness of the custodial environment and the ability of each parent to provide emotional and physical security (*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219 (1998); *Guardianship of Estelle*, 70 Mass. App. Ct. 575 (2007); *Custody of a Minor (No. 1)*, 377 Mass. 876 (1979)).
*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).support_reasoning: The opinion applies the statutory best-interests standard by explicitly weighing the quality of each proposed custodial environment and each caretaker’s demonstrated capacity to meet the child’s emotional, developmental, and physical needs. The court emphasizes Hugo’s need for a stable, predictable home, assesses how each prospective parent can provide support for his special needs, and affirms that these kinds of comparative fitness and caregiving-capacity evaluations are central to the best-interests inquiry. While it does not use the exact phrasing of the proposition, its reasoning is consistent with and supports that principle.
*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).relevant_excerpt: “Here, the judge had to weigh the benefits of stability, of keeping Hugo in his present home, with moving him to a family where, in his judgment, it is more likely that Hugo will receive the home support, stability, and reinforcement of efforts to address his developmental needs so critical to his future development.… [T]he judge appropriately considered the personal, educational, psychological, and other support available to each prospective parent to address Hugo’s needs.”

*Guardianship of Estelle*, 70 Mass. App..proposition: In determining the children’s best interests, the Court must consider the fitness of the custodial environment and the ability of each parent to provide emotional and physical security (*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219 (1998); *Guardianship of Estelle*, 70 Mass. App. Ct. 575 (2007); *Custody of a Minor (No. 1)*, 377 Mass. 876 (1979)).
*Guardianship of Estelle*, 70 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly frames the parental fitness inquiry as inseparable from the child’s best interests and requires considering the parent’s willingness and ability to care for the child and the effect on the child of being in that parent’s custody. The court emphasizes that fitness is measured by circumstances within the family as they affect the child’s welfare, including the impact of changing the custodial environment and the parent’s capacity to address the child’s emotional needs. This aligns with the proposition that the court must evaluate the fitness of the custodial environment and each parent’s ability to provide emotional and physical security when determining best interests.
*Guardianship of Estelle*, 70 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: “‘The term [“unfitness”] is a standard by which we measure the circumstances within the family as they affect the child’s welfare.’… At a minimum, the fitness of a particular parent cannot be judged without a consideration of that parent’s willingness and ability to care for the child, as well as the effect on a child of being placed in the custody of that parent. One who is fit to parent in some circumstances may not be fit if the circumstances are otherwise. … [T]here must be attention to the effect on this child of whatever separation from the uncle and aunt would come about if there is a transfer to the father, including whether the father is prepared and able to cope adequately with the child’s trauma….”}

*Custody of a Minor (No. 1)*, 377 Mass..proposition: In determining the children’s best interests, the Court must consider the fitness of the custodial environment and the ability of each parent to provide emotional and physical security (*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219 (1998); *Guardianship of Estelle*, 70 Mass. App. Ct. 575 (2007); *Custody of a Minor (No. 1)*, 377 Mass. 876 (1979)).
*Custody of a Minor (No. 1)*, 377 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on the need for a finding of current parental unfitness and on procedural protections (specific, detailed findings) before the State may remove a child, rather than articulating a best‑interests test that requires consideration of the “fitness of the custodial environment” and “the ability of each parent to provide emotional and physical security.” It discusses parents’ ability to provide basic necessities and protection from neglect, but not in the later Hugo/Estelle formulation about comparative parental ability and emotional security in a best‑interests custody framework. Thus it only indirectly relates to, and does not clearly establish, the proposition as stated.
*Custody of a Minor (No. 1)*, 377 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “Because the interest of the child is thought to be best served in the stable, continuous environment of his own family… State intervention in the parent-child relationship is justified only when parents appear unable to provide for their children’s care and protection. … We therefore think it plain that the judge was warranted in determining the mother’s newborn child to be in need of care and protection at the time of trial. The uncontested facts… indicate that the mother is incapable of providing the basic necessities of food and shelter, ignorant of proper child care and supervision….”
